title: Support Unicode literals in templates
body: Sometimes, it makes sense to format a character in a string literal-- ``` {{ "{0} is fantastic".format(user.full_name) }} ``` However, this will fail with a UnicodeEncodeError if user.full_name is a Unicode string with non-ASCII characters in it. Jinja2 does not support unicode string literals, so one must work around this problem like so-- ``` {{ "{0} is fantastic".decode("utf8").format(user.full_name) }} ``` This is icky. Could Jinja2 be changed in the future to support the Unicode literal? Our example code would look like this-- ``` {{ u"{0} is fantastic".format(user.full_name) }} ``` This mirrors what you would likely do in a Python script, which I think is what Jinja2 is going for. Aside: I think you might be wondering what the real use case is for this. Obviously, in the example I've used it would be easy to just write this: ``` {{ user.full_name }} is fantastic! ``` One example of where a unicode literal makes sense is encoding a querystring. For example, imagine we have a mailto link with some default body and subject text, which we want to format. This pattern makes sense: ``` {% set mailto_dict = { "body": "{0} is fantastic!".decode("utf8").format(user.full_name), "subject": "And this is some example text! Sincerely, {0}".decode("utf8").format(business.full_name), } %} Send an email ``` But all those `decode("utf8")` are icky. It would be much nicer to use a Unicode literal.
